Under the superntcnlcnce and instruction Of

female teachers.


The course Of instruction pursued at this sem
inary, comprises all the useful, and most Of the
ornamental branches Of female educatnn. The
daily exercises are Orthogrsphy, Reading, Writ
ing, Arithmetic, inSlish Grammar, Rhetoric;
Geography and History, ancient ana modern,
with constant reference to the best maps and
charts Construction OF maps; use Of the Globes;
Natural History; Natural Philosophy, including
Astronomy aud Chcmistryi Elements OF MoiSl
Science.


Htehg Ere-c'vs.-Biblica Rccitations; Eyi-
dcnccs Of Christianity; Letter nting, and 9TH
CT species Ot Composition; Rccapitulations.


1erms.--Board and tuition, in any Of the fore
going branches, sJ2, 80 per quarter; or, if paid
in advance, $50. Music, including the use Of a
piano, SIP, French, by one OF the best masters,
50 per quarter Moderate extra charges for
Drawing and o,hcr ornamental branches.


The discipline Of the school is mild, parental,
and christian. Particular attention is paid not
only TO the manners OF the young ladies, but 10
their moral and religious instruction. They arc
regularly conducted to such places Of worship
and SUNDAY Schools, as their parents and guar
dians approve. Exercise and recreation, being
essential 10 the prescr alton Of health and Of
mental energy, occupy thu intervals Of time not
devoted to study. The institution, in all its de-
partments, is conducted in a MANNER which it
is hoped, viii meet tie entire appreciation Of its
patrons.

SPRING GOODS.

For the first ten years after your cores
pondent had become the proprietor OF gar
den. there was no plant that he attempted
to raise, attended with so much difficulty as
that of the cabbage. The strongest manure
was used. and the plants well tended, but e
very attempt failed of success. The main
root became clumped, and the smaller enes
full of large knots--the plants withered and
died. BY the direction of an old gardener,
a different course was pursued, and for 20
years past has never failed, snd now there
Is no plant that he Can raise with more ease
-ahan the one above named. During the said
20 years, one kind OF cabbage was princi-
palIy planted--the seed was raised from
time to time, generally from large heads
The cabbage improved in size, growing
larger, until they grew too large for the use
Of small family" and smaller kind was
substituted.
CABBAGES.

Two Gooseberry bushes are described in
the horticultural Transactions; the branches
on one at the seat of the late Sir Joseph
Banks. extended u yards in circumference,
and produce several peckso Of fruit annually.
1t is manured with soap sudS and the drain
ings from the dung hill. Arother is trained
to a building measuring 55 teet from one
extremity to the other, and produces annual
ly from four to FIVE pecks OF fruit.

NOTICE.

The method pursued was as follows. AZ
ter the ground is well pulverised by the
plough, dig holes which will hold about half
bushel, and from two and half to three
feet asuDder-put into each hole about two
quarts Of fine old manure from the barh-
yard, and from one TO two pints of dry ash
es-draw the earth dug out back, and with
hoe mix or incorporate the whole well to-
gether, and leave the place little concave'
Place two plants in each hill from SIX to
eight inches apart. and when one begins to
interfere with the other, remove the least
promising. The plants should be set just
before a shower, or in the evening, taking
care not to press the earth too hard about
the roots. II the weather be dry, the plants
ought t,. be lightly shaded for one or two
days, and perhaps little water may be ne
cessary

IfIr. Sk1HH6T--l nCiO i95 PNi" "'t'Hf ~
ease in this climate from which our neat
,.,ttlr have suffered so much that com
,nonlv called the Hollow Horn; and nntortu-
nately. few persons have thought it necessa-
ry to give any attention to it, or its cure, tor
we find but little said in any agricultural
work relative TO its treatment.


The name appears to me to be badly ap-
piled, as the horn alone is not the seat OF tne
disease; it prevades the whole system--anu
cattle without horns are quite as SUBJECT 70
il. as those with thcm--having often seen
those without horns have II.


The holiovness of the horn, proceeds
from the violence of the fever throughout
the system. have known cattle feeding IN
stalls to he attacked with it, as we'll as those
in Door condition; and no doubt those IN poor
plight are more liable to its attack tl"r
system not being in a state to resist any dis
ease, it occurs too at all seasons OF the year,
but more particularly in the spring


The animal attacked with it. looks rough;
cta,es much in its coat aud falls off very
fast in flesh, its food having but httlc effect
IN nourishing it, The eye looks very hollow
and dead and runs with yellow matter
which collects in the corners, and around
them. Many persons rely upon the teel OF
the horn, as the best indicative OF the dis-
ease, but this, | think very uncertain; ~
sone cases it il At the root, cold to the feel,
while in others very hot A very small
einblet will, however, remove all doubts,
aud the mark on the horn not vlsl-
bic after a few days. II the disease eX-
ists the horn will be found without pitn, and
little or no blood will follow the boring
whereas if the disease does not exist, you
WIZ find blood immediately upon entering
the horn. The gimblet used for boring
Cd nd apt Litter IL
sing; for if il is not, and should be used - tr!
the horn of an animal not actually afccted
with the disease, it will most genrr1liy give
it to them 1t is disease that is hlshli IN
hammatory and infectious; and The arlmai
having it, oughtto be removed from :he herd
until we'll. The following mode OF treat
nent, have found very sue eSsiul, and Ne
beast soon restored 10 thriving state As
soon as discover an animal affected with
the hollow horn, | bleed It from the neck
lin the same VEN in which horse IS bled)
from two to six or seven quarts, according
TO its age, size, and condition, and gave II
from three quarters 70 one pound ana nan
Rlauber salts; with middle sized gimh!et
open the horns through and through, making
the holes, so that they may be perpendltuiar
in the usual position the animal carries rs
head. so that the pus formed may have a





ed, put through the hole into each about a
table spoonful of strong vinegar, IN which
xome salt and black pepper ground, mas
been put. The day following, the horns
must be again opened and cleaned from tho
pus, which generally is new formed, and
about half a tea spoonful of spirits OF turpen-
sine, put into each horn, and little on the
poll Of the animal daily, during the contnu-
ance of the disease. One bleeding is gcner-
ally sufficient; but have known cases in
which it was necessary to repeat it three
times, as also the salts.


The food during the continuance OF the
disease is important-con in every shape
is bad-potatoes are of great use, (wlth a
small qSantity of Brewers grains, # to be
had) and the animal ought to have from one
to one and half pecks daily with hay IN
the winter, and grass II IN summer


Potatoes have a wonderful effect on III.
animal as soon as the bowels are well cleans
ed, the importance of which, any persoT
will be Convinced of, who observes the dis
charge from the animal In some obstinate
cases have given daily, from half to one
ounce of nitrr, sprink ed on the potatoes. Il
Is important at the FIRST bleeding to take a.
much blood as the animal will beal, as the
fever is more easily checked by one large
bleeding. than two small ones, and the nnin'
al better able to bear il.


In many cases the bleeding and salts have
been sufficient, without opening the horns
and when taken in the early stage will gen
orally be found to answer, but the boarin!
certainly assists in tOrminE anew, the inter
nal part Of the horn, and which, as soon a
it commences forming, the holes il the horl
should be allowed to close.


An animal having the hollow horn, SHOULD
be sheltered from the nclemency Of tn
weather, during its continuance. No ag
appears exempt from its attack, havin
seen it in a yearling as well as at subsequeu
ages. am induced to offer this mode {
treatment to your subscribers, having ueve
in any instance failed Of restoring the amin
al, whereas before this mode of treatmct
was adopted annually lost several. Th
fieam for bleeding cattle should be raths
deeper than used for horse, the vein in III
neck, not lying SO near the surface; the or
fee is closed with pin, in the same was
In bleeding horse.

without taste or color, which children at
nictcd with the summer complaint will
drink freely, and it y said tn be the bes'
remedy ever discovered. lC has been sup
posed that [und' freN'iyooel the live, o.
three hubdr' 4 children we've saved by tla,t
summer ia B.'t aorc, ana know the eff
cacy ct it hy eX. crieucr IN my own family
Benr seed OIL is said 20 be equal to Fiol {.
This plant viii throw out greater prniu
sion OF leaves, ~ breaking off the top wheo

full articles.headline:
Young Ladies' Boarding School.


AT WIINnNLTON, DELAWARE.
full articles.article:
Under the superntcnlcnce and instruction Of
WILLIAM SIIEkER, assisted BY accomplished
female teachers.


The course Of instruction pursued at this sem
inary, comprises all the useful, and most Of the
ornamental branches Of female educatnn. The
daily exercises are Orthogrsphy, Reading, Writ
ing, Arithmetic, inSlish Grammar, Rhetoric;
Geography and History, ancient ana modern,
with constant reference to the best maps and
charts Construction OF maps; use Of the Globes;
Natural History; Natural Philosophy, including
Astronomy aud Chcmistryi Elements OF MoiSl
Science.


Htehg Ere-c'vs.-Biblica Rccitations; Eyi-
dcnccs Of Christianity; Letter nting, and 9TH
CT species Ot Composition; Rccapitulations.


1erms.--Board and tuition, in any Of the fore
going branches, sJ2, 80 per quarter; or, if paid
in advance, $50. Music, including the use Of a
piano, SIP, French, by one OF the best masters,
50 per quarter Moderate extra charges for
Drawing and o,hcr ornamental branches.


The discipline Of the school is mild, parental,
and christian. Particular attention is paid not
only TO the manners OF the young ladies, but 10
their moral and religious instruction. They arc
regularly conducted to such places Of worship
and SUNDAY Schools, as their parents and guar
dians approve. Exercise and recreation, being
essential 10 the prescr alton Of health and Of
mental energy, occupy thu intervals Of time not
devoted to study. The institution, in all its de-
partments, is conducted in a MANNER which it
is hoped, viii meet tie entire appreciation Of its
patrons.

full articles.headline: WOOL CARDING.
full articles.article:
fOHN BANCROFT, having removed from


~ Brsndywine Bridge, 10 Providence Facto-
ry, Delaware Co Pa, takes this means to in
form his friends and the public generally, that
he there continues the Cardng of Wool, for all
those who are pleased to favor him with their
customs and that he hopes by strict attention and
punctualty, to merit a continuance of pub.
lie patronage. lie also takes this opportunity
to inform tl,ose to whose favor he was indebted
for work this line, while at Brandywine Bridge,
that all wool left forhim to card, at John Torbcrt's
Store, or at the soap Factory of Brainton s: Ban
croft, wilmington, or at WIN. M'Cauley's Store
Brandy vine, will be taken from thence onre ev-
cry week, and, being carded, will he punctually
et'Inred the week following; hoping, by the a
boye arrangement, and punctualiy in the return
and good performance of the work confded TO
him. they may be induced to continue their ia.
YOURS.

full articles.headline: CABBAGES.
full articles.article:
For the first ten years after your cores
pondent had become the proprietor OF gar
den. there was no plant that he attempted
to raise, attended with so much difficulty as
that of the cabbage. The strongest manure
was used. and the plants well tended, but e
very attempt failed of success. The main
root became clumped, and the smaller enes
full of large knots--the plants withered and
died. BY the direction of an old gardener,
a different course was pursued, and for 20
years past has never failed, snd now there
Is no plant that he Can raise with more ease
-ahan the one above named. During the said
20 years, one kind OF cabbage was princi-
palIy planted--the seed was raised from
time to time, generally from large heads
The cabbage improved in size, growing
larger, until they grew too large for the use
Of small family" and smaller kind was
substituted.

Two Gooseberry bushes are described in
the horticultural Transactions; the branches
on one at the seat of the late Sir Joseph
Banks. extended u yards in circumference,
and produce several peckso Of fruit annually.
1t is manured with soap sudS and the drain
ings from the dung hill. Arother is trained
to a building measuring 55 teet from one
extremity to the other, and produces annual
ly from four to FIVE pecks OF fruit.

full articles.headline: NOTICE.
full articles.article:
All persons indebted to the Estate Of
ALEXANDER CALENDER. deceased
late of Newcastle Hundred and County, De-
laware, are requested to make immediate
settlement. and those having claims against
said estate, are likewise requested to present
them, legally attested, to


ISAAC THOMAS, Admir-.
Chrstiana Bridge, April 10, 1927.


Hl=6W.

The method pursued was as follows. AZ
ter the ground is well pulverised by the
plough, dig holes which will hold about half
bushel, and from two and half to three
feet asuDder-put into each hole about two
quarts Of fine old manure from the barh-
yard, and from one TO two pints of dry ash
es-draw the earth dug out back, and with
hoe mix or incorporate the whole well to-
gether, and leave the place little concave'
Place two plants in each hill from SIX to
eight inches apart. and when one begins to
interfere with the other, remove the least
promising. The plants should be set just
before a shower, or in the evening, taking
care not to press the earth too hard about
the roots. II the weather be dry, the plants
ought t,. be lightly shaded for one or two
days, and perhaps little water may be ne
cessary

full articles.headline:
TyEE FAR EirE5R.

From the American Farmer
full articles.article:
IfIr. Sk1HH6T--l nCiO i95 PNi" "'t'Hf ~
ease in this climate from which our neat
,.,ttlr have suffered so much that com
,nonlv called the Hollow Horn; and nntortu-
nately. few persons have thought it necessa-
ry to give any attention to it, or its cure, tor
we find but little said in any agricultural
work relative TO its treatment.


The name appears to me to be badly ap-
piled, as the horn alone is not the seat OF tne
disease; it prevades the whole system--anu
cattle without horns are quite as SUBJECT 70
il. as those with thcm--having often seen
those without horns have II.


The holiovness of the horn, proceeds
from the violence of the fever throughout
the system. have known cattle feeding IN
stalls to he attacked with it, as we'll as those
in Door condition; and no doubt those IN poor
plight are more liable to its attack tl"r
system not being in a state to resist any dis
ease, it occurs too at all seasons OF the year,
but more particularly in the spring


The animal attacked with it. looks rough;
cta,es much in its coat aud falls off very
fast in flesh, its food having but httlc effect
IN nourishing it, The eye looks very hollow
and dead and runs with yellow matter
which collects in the corners, and around
them. Many persons rely upon the teel OF
the horn, as the best indicative OF the dis-
ease, but this, | think very uncertain; ~
sone cases it il At the root, cold to the feel,
while in others very hot A very small
einblet will, however, remove all doubts,
aud the mark on the horn not vlsl-
bic after a few days. II the disease eX-
ists the horn will be found without pitn, and
little or no blood will follow the boring
whereas if the disease does not exist, you
WIZ find blood immediately upon entering
the horn. The gimblet used for boring
Cd nd apt Litter IL
sing; for if il is not, and should be used - tr!
the horn of an animal not actually afccted
with the disease, it will most genrr1liy give
it to them 1t is disease that is hlshli IN
hammatory and infectious; and The arlmai
having it, oughtto be removed from :he herd
until we'll. The following mode OF treat
nent, have found very sue eSsiul, and Ne
beast soon restored 10 thriving state As
soon as discover an animal affected with
the hollow horn, | bleed It from the neck
lin the same VEN in which horse IS bled)
from two to six or seven quarts, according
TO its age, size, and condition, and gave II
from three quarters 70 one pound ana nan
Rlauber salts; with middle sized gimh!et
open the horns through and through, making
the holes, so that they may be perpendltuiar
in the usual position the animal carries rs
head. so that the pus formed may have a





ed, put through the hole into each about a
table spoonful of strong vinegar, IN which
xome salt and black pepper ground, mas
been put. The day following, the horns
must be again opened and cleaned from tho
pus, which generally is new formed, and
about half a tea spoonful of spirits OF turpen-
sine, put into each horn, and little on the
poll Of the animal daily, during the contnu-
ance of the disease. One bleeding is gcner-
ally sufficient; but have known cases in
which it was necessary to repeat it three
times, as also the salts.


The food during the continuance OF the
disease is important-con in every shape
is bad-potatoes are of great use, (wlth a
small qSantity of Brewers grains, # to be
had) and the animal ought to have from one
to one and half pecks daily with hay IN
the winter, and grass II IN summer


Potatoes have a wonderful effect on III.
animal as soon as the bowels are well cleans
ed, the importance of which, any persoT
will be Convinced of, who observes the dis
charge from the animal In some obstinate
cases have given daily, from half to one
ounce of nitrr, sprink ed on the potatoes. Il
Is important at the FIRST bleeding to take a.
much blood as the animal will beal, as the
fever is more easily checked by one large
bleeding. than two small ones, and the nnin'
al better able to bear il.


In many cases the bleeding and salts have
been sufficient, without opening the horns
and when taken in the early stage will gen
orally be found to answer, but the boarin!
certainly assists in tOrminE anew, the inter
nal part Of the horn, and which, as soon a
it commences forming, the holes il the horl
should be allowed to close.


An animal having the hollow horn, SHOULD
be sheltered from the nclemency Of tn
weather, during its continuance. No ag
appears exempt from its attack, havin
seen it in a yearling as well as at subsequeu
ages. am induced to offer this mode {
treatment to your subscribers, having ueve
in any instance failed Of restoring the amin
al, whereas before this mode of treatmct
was adopted annually lost several. Th
fieam for bleeding cattle should be raths
deeper than used for horse, the vein in III
neck, not lying SO near the surface; the or
fee is closed with pin, in the same was
In bleeding horse.


AN AGRICuLTuRIST
full articles.byline:
On the disease COMMONLY callca ne

HOLLOW HORN.

full articles.headline: RENE PLANT.
full articles.article:
This valuable medicinal plant is but little
known IN the northern states the propri-
etors have lately received some ofthe seed
from friend in Virginia who writes 70
Messrs Thnrburn < Son. that it requires to
be sown early IN Aprh, at Il distance Of a.
bout one foot apart A few leaves Of the
plant, when green plunged a few times in a
tumbIer OF water, make it Ike thin jcllcN;
without taste or color, which children at
nictcd with the summer complaint will
drink freely, and it y said tn be the bes'
remedy ever discovered. lC has been sup
posed that [und' freN'iyooel the live, o.
three hubdr' 4 children we've saved by tla,t
summer ia B.'t aorc, ana know the eff
cacy ct it hy eX. crieucr IN my own family
Benr seed OIL is said 20 be equal to Fiol {.
This plant viii throw out greater prniu
sion OF leaves, ~ breaking off the top wheo
it is A0out ha' growi
